# AnOceanintheSky
https://brilliant.org/daily-problems/sky-ocean/


<p>Rainstorms are a double-edged sword, they’re good for plants and help us drift off to sleep, but they turn our commutes into a nightmare. People of all kinds are united in facing the timeless question “will I stay drier if I run or if I walk through this rain?” </p>





<p>That’s a question we’ll address in Tuesday and Wednesday’s daily problems, but first we need to think about how rain falls through the atmosphere.</p>

<p>Water exists in an endless cycle of evaporation from oceans, seas, and lakes into water vapour, condensation from vapour into liquid raindrops, and deposition back into bodies of water. </p>

<p></p><div class="image-caption center">
<div class="zoomable-image"><span></span><img src="https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/29aVgiQ91I-matter2.png?width=600" srcset="https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/29aVgiQ91I-matter2.png?width=600 1x,https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/29aVgiQ91I-matter2.png?width=1200 2x,https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/29aVgiQ91I-matter2.png?width=1800 3x" alt="" style="width:600px;max-width:100%;"></div>
</div><p></p>

<p>The amount that is in the sky depends on a number of factors, including the temperature of the air and water, solar radiation on the body of water, wind speed, and prevailing ocean currents that transport heat around the globe. This is why some areas are consistently desert while others have rain nearly every day of the year.</p>

<p>When warm water is under a receptive atmosphere, there can be mass movement of water from ocean to sky. This is the source of the <span class="latexprocessor-inline latexprocessor-bd6b0fa61b0b8538627ad58feaa592a98a028c5220e5efe91bf1b667f14249a0"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" 361Q302 397 257 397Z"></path><path id="MJMAIN-4C-20b9d6fa332c11e9a5c902b7b6aa3886f66a7ec34b4d485aa930d027ee9760c0" stroke-width="0" d="M128 622Q121 629 117 631T101 634T58 637H25V683H36Q48 680 182 xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4C-20b9d6fa332c11e9a5c902b7b6aa3886f66a7ec34b4d485aa930d027ee9760c0" x="3085" y="0"></use></g></svg></span> of water in the atmosphere (roughly the volume of water in the Persian gulf), mostly in the form of clouds and water vapour.</p>

<p>If humid air cools (e.g. via a cold front, or by rising through the atmosphere) then water will condense around dust particles (like steam condensing on a cold mirror) to form raindrops, and fall back to Earth. Typical raindrop sizes range all the way from the sub-millimeter range, up to about <span class="latexprocessor-inline latexprocessor-a8858d51972fa7adbf235da35cdf234539b3fad18524c7d58e9a726a26e99d8f"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" style="width: 7.111ex; height: 1.667ex; vertical-align: -0.222ex; 130T362 333Q362 478 354 524T321 597Z"></path><path id="MJMAIN-6D-172ad5ee332c11e9a5c902b7b6aa38864a420e9a188e4f648944ac3bcabc63aa" stroke-width="0" d="M41 46H55Q94 46 102 60V68Q102 77 102 91T102 <p></p><div class="image-caption center">
<div class="zoomable-image"><span></span><img src="https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/HzFri3JM4L-frame-85.svg?width=600" srcset="https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/HzFri3JM4L-frame-85.svg?width=600 1x,https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/HzFri3JM4L-frame-85.svg?width=1200 2x,https://ds055uzetaobb.cloudfront.net/brioche/uploads/HzFri3JM4L-frame-85.svg?width=1800 3x" alt="" style="width:600px;max-width:100%;"></div>
</div><p></p>

<p>The speed of a raindrop on its way to the surface is determined by the opposing effects of gravity and the force of wind resistance. The balance point varies by size, but for typical droplets terminal velocity works out to be roughly <span class="latexprocessor-inline latexprocessor-033341605c023b71a3d66ab81c294588893bc981e7eb7f4a6c3123eb35c2ed64"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" style="width: 7.5ex; height: 2.375ex; vertical-align: -0.75ex; 130T362 333Q362 478 354 524T321 597Z"></path><path id="MJMAIN-6D-b23d115acf0011e7879e0214570faa50796042c55bcf443b88a8c67af66a5a9f" stroke-width="0" d="M41 46H55Q94 46 102 60V68Q102 77 102 91T102 <div class="b-readable-l">
<header class="b-vspace-m">
<h1>Today's Problem</h1>
</header>

<div class="solv-problem">
<div class="solv-content">




<div class="question-text latex">





<p>Just as you’re about to leave for work from home, a storm front rolls in and starts depositing heavy rain at a rate of <span class="latexprocessor-inline latexprocessor-cb15a9dac3693e5843c2b0ebf2b11d029edef8c3e37df594fe9dc7acd00b8844"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" style="width: 8.556ex; height: 2.444ex; vertical-align: -0.778ex; <p>Approximately what fraction, by volume, do the raindrops occupy in the air?</p>

# 내 멋대로 발직역
# 제목

<div class="b-readable-l">
<header class="b-vspace-m">
<h1>Today's Problem</h1>
</header>

<div class="solv-problem">
<div class="solv-content">




<div class="question-text latex">
